title: The race to sequence the human genome - Tien Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial planned duration of the Human Genome Project?

What was the main difference between the Human Genome Project's approach and Celera's approach?

options.label: A
options.text: The Human Genome Project used a faster approach, while Celera used a slower approach.

options.label: B
options.text: The Human Genome Project divided the genome into smaller chunks, while Celera chopped the genome into small, overlapping bits.

options.label: C
options.text: The Human Genome Project minimized the risk of misassembly, while Celera's approach was faster but riskier.

options.label: D
options.text: The Human Genome Project used a whole genome shotgun sequencing approach, while Celera used hierarchical shotgun sequencing.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The pace of research was accelerated.

options.label: C
options.text: The project was completed in 15 years.

options.label: D
options.text: The project was completed in 20 years.

multiple-choice.question: In what year was the Human Genome Project completed?
What was the result of the competition between the Human Genome Project and Celera?

options.label: A
options.text: The Human Genome Project completed the project in 15 years.

options.label: B
options.text: Celera completed the project in 3 years.

options.label: C
options.text: The Human Genome Project and Celera completed the project simultaneously.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main principle of the Human Genome Project?

options.label: A
options.text: Collaboration on our shared heritage was open to all nations.

options.label: B
options.text: All data would be shared publicly within 24 hours of collection.

options.label: C
options.text: The project would be completed in 15 years.

options.label: D
options.text: The project would be completed at a cost of $3 billion.

multiple-choice.question: What was the technology used by the Human Genome Project to sequence the genome?

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Growth Mindset vs Fixed Mindset: An Introduction

multiple-choice.question: What do people with a growth mindset believe about intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a fixed trait that cannot be changed.

options.label: B
options.text: It can be developed through effort and learning.

options.label: C
options.text: It is like eye color, something you're born with.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a muscle that can be developed through challenge and effort.

multiple-choice.question: What do people with a fixed mindset believe about intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: It can be developed through effort and learning.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a fixed trait that cannot be changed.

options.label: C
options.text: It is like a muscle that can be developed through challenge and effort.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a skill that can be learned.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a growth mindset tend to disagree with?

options.label: A
options.text: Statements that suggest intelligence is fixed.

options.label: B
options.text: Statements that suggest intelligence is a skill that can be learned.

options.label: C
options.text: Statements that suggest effort is a sign of lack of intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Statements that suggest challenges are opportunities to learn.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of students with a fixed mindset in school?

options.label: A
options.text: To learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: To show how smart they are or hide how unintelligent they are.

options.label: C
options.text: To ask questions when they don't understand something.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a growth mindset view effort as?

options.label: A
options.text: A sign of lack of intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: A positive means of learning and developing their intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to avoid challenges and setbacks.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to show how smart they are.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a fixed mindset tend to do when faced with challenges or setbacks?

options.label: A
options.text: See challenges as opportunities to learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: B
options.text: Give up because they think their setback means they're not smart.

options.label: C
options.text: Ask questions when they don't understand something.

options.label: D
options.text: View effort as a positive means of learning.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a growth mindset tend to do when faced with challenges or setbacks?

options.label: A
options.text: Give up because their setback means they're not smart.

options.label: B
options.text: See challenges as opportunities to learn and develop their intelligence.

options.label: C
options.text: View effort as a sign of lack of intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoid asking questions when they don't understand something.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between students with fixed and growth mindsets?

options.label: A
options.text: The way they view effort and challenge.

options.label: D
options.text: The way they view challenges and setbacks.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a growth mindset focus on in school?

options.label: A
options.text: Showing how smart they are or hiding how unintelligent they are.

options.label: C
options.text: Asking questions when they don't understand something.

multiple-choice.question: What do students with a fixed mindset view as a sign of lack of intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Asking questions when they don't understand something.

options.label: B
options.text: Viewing effort as a positive means of learning.

options.label: C
options.text: Viewing effort as a sign of lack of intelligence.

options.label: D
options.text: Giving up when faced with challenges or setbacks.
